Jobs at University of Papua New Guinea: The University of Papua New Guinea, is an independent, statutory Institution of Higher Education, established by The University of Papua New Guinea Ordinance 1965, confirmed bythe University of PNG Act No. 18 of 1983.The University is dedicated to the pursuit, advancement and dissemination of knowledge, understanding and wisdom. Jobs at University of Papua New Guinea The University is currently undergoing significant infrastructure and service improvement initiatives as it strives to reform, reposition and transform the University into an influential, global academic institution. It envisions to build capacity and capability of the workforce and is immediately seeking to employ suitably qualified and experienced career professionals to fill the following key positions with its strategic business units (Schools & Divisions) based at the University Main Campus. 1. DECOLONISING YOUR OWN EDUCATION: How many have read this book? A mere 745 pages in translation of a Mughal emperors diary. Not the easiest of reads. Certainly needed stamina to plough through the language. But a good time to read about governance of the sub-continent by one of us. Jahangir known today mostly for his tomb in Lahore, his wife Noor Jahan and son Shah Jahan. Often we are caught in the glamour of woke titles of governance from a western-centric lens with flashy book jackets. But, given the collapse of capitalism, democracy, the first world order and what one might have thought was reasonable rhetoric a few decades ago, this is an opportunity to learn about us, written by us, our ancestors. A hidden authentic , culturally, geographically and climatically appropriate history of power & governance. The best time to start consciously decolonise one‚Äôs thought process, not looking west for answers but creating imaginative solutions to regional problems by going back to our own regional roots.

A rapid increase in enrollments has caused a shortage of trained teachers. The shortage of experienced teachers may result in low-qualified teachers, lack of public value accountability and integrity, unethical behaviour, and corruption that requires policy adjustments. üü©The context, content, and learning outcome of this public lecture improved the education stakeholders/policymakers/Civil Society, etc. actors and institutions' representative education policy decision-making process, design, implementation, governance, administration, management, and professional development for Teachers in connection with on/offline and hybrid classes in the real world and African education and learning agenda settings for our common good. ‚ö†Ô∏èSlide 1 indicates my End and Take away message ‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ† For your individual and institutional/university participation in my (on/ofline and Hybrid) research training, mentoring guidance, and (external) supervision possibilities. Contact me directly through my correspondence email below for the research training and mentoring guidance organisation, requirements, and logistics arrangements. eddy_bruno11@yahoo.com ‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ† Guarantor & Lecturer Prof. Dr Eddy Bruno Esien, PhD Prof and Doctor in Public & Social Policy Care, Education & Knowledge, and (e)Governance Expert (Business) Research Methodology and Methods Professor/Mentor ‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†

There seem to be a number of calls for trustees, steering group, and board members for academic organisations recently. This is really important as there are many areas where instruction, guidance, and governance is needed across a sector where there are many areas needing improvement and evidence to apply in a critical and thoughtful manner. For all these calls I've seen they require applicants to be employed (full time) in a university. This is missing those who are part time; consultants and coaches; independent scholars; or who undertake academic practices (e.g. research) in non-university settings. This feels limiting to me, it misses so many core skills that practitioner researchers, indie academics, or consultants have. It seems wrong that someone with a moderate amount of skills from a university can apply, while a highly experienced person who works across multiple universities, or even is advising universities on how to improve their practices would not be eligible. How might we change this frustrating and limiting approach?

Reading comprehension is a skill and not one that everyone possesses in equal measure. Literacy rates are topping out near 100 per cent in many parts of the world. But this apparent progress masks a hidden problem. Like many things, literacy is a spectrum. Experts have identified six literacy levels, which they‚Äôve labelled 0 to 5. Level 3 is considered the minimum competency needed for everyday functioning. So we‚Äôd expect most people to have a literacy level of 3 or higher, right? Wrong. According to the Program for the International Assessment of Adult Competencies, 52 per cent of adults in the United States have a literacy level of 0, 1 or 2. They might struggle to follow recipes and other instructions; apply for jobs or unemployment benefit; write emails; pass the written portion of a driving test; understand medical charts, lease agreements and household bills, let alone vote; post on social media; decipher think pieces and academic articles; read the latest Booker Prize winner; or make sense of this sentence. What‚Äôs going on? The reasons are too complex to properly disambiguate here, but suffice it to say that having a low literacy level does not mean someone is stupid or lazy. Everything from neurological makeup to quality of schooling to socioeconomic status and socialisation to nonnative status can impede acquisition and retention of these skills. Moreover, learning how to read is not like learning to ride a bike. It‚Äôs more comparable to complex maths. Without practice, one‚Äôs literacy level will decline over time. Check out the full piece on our site to find out what this means for legal texts, what New Zealand has done to demystify public policy and more: https://lnkd.in/eRu2u58C. #Literacy #Writing #Jargon #ContentMarketing #MarketingAgency

üì£ Calling all international educators! üì£ üì£ I‚Äôll be in Nairobi, Kenya on October 4th for an engaging seminar on "The Whole Student View: Piecing Together Your Student Data Puzzle." Don't miss this opportunity to enhance your educational practices! Discover how to effectively use assessment data to ensure every student achieves their full potential. Combine measures of attainment, ability, and attitude to build a unique personal profile for each student. Gain insights on: üìä Establishing an accurate baseline: Learn how to measure cognitive and reasoning abilities, identify gifted and talented students, and inform curriculum planning. üìö Identifying reading and literacy support needs: Explore benchmarked assessments to differentiate teaching based on students' reading and comprehension skills. üíö Improving student engagement and wellbeing: Utilise attitudinal surveys to assess student wellbeing, identify support needs, and evaluate the impact of interventions. Attendees will gain an understanding of the data triangle, learn to combine data for a comprehensive view of each student, and master personalised teaching techniques. Secure your spot now!
